pli-tv-pvr7:28.1: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of condemnation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.2: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.

pli-tv-pvr7:28.4: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he is constantly and improperly socializing with householders.

pli-tv-pvr7:28.7: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of reconciliation against him:
pli-tv-pvr7:28.8: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; he abuses and reviles householders.

pli-tv-pvr7:28.10: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; after committing an offense, he refuses to recognize it.

pli-tv-pvr7:28.12: he is quarrelsome, argumentative, and a creator of legal issues in the Sangha; he is ignorant and incompetent, often committing offenses, incapable of determining whether he has committed an offense; after committing an offense, he refuses to make amends for it.
pli-tv-pvr7:28.13: When a monk has three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of ejecting him for not giving up a bad view:

pli-tv-pvr7:50.6: There are offenses committed by residents, not by those departing.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.7: There are offenses committed both by those departing and by residents.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.8: There are offenses committed neither by those departing nor by residents.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.9: There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense; there are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense; there are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense; there are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.10: There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense; there are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense; there are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared; there are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.11: There are offenses committed by the preceptor, but not the student; there are offenses committed by the student, but not the preceptor; there are offenses committed by both the preceptor and the student; there are offenses committed by neither the preceptor nor the student.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.12: There are offenses committed by the teacher, but not the pupil; there are offenses committed by the pupil, but not the teacher; there are offenses committed by both the teacher and the pupil; there are offenses committed by neither the teacher nor the pupil.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.13: There is no offense for breaking the rainy-season residence for these four reasons:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.14: there is a schism in the Sangha; there are some who wants to cause a schism in the Sangha; there is a threat to life; there is a threat to the monastic life.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.15: There are four kinds of bad conduct by speech:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.16: lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and idle speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.17: There are four kinds of good conduct by speech:
pli-tv-pvr7:50.18: truthful speech, non-divisive speech, gentle speech, and meaningful speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.19: There are offenses that are serious when doing them oneself, but light when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.20: There are offenses that are light when doing them oneself, but serious when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.21: There are offenses that are serious both when doing them oneself and when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.22: There are offenses that are light both when doing them oneself and when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.1: There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not being stood up for.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.3: There are people who deserve both being bowed down to and being stood up for.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.4: There are people who deserve neither being bowed down to nor being stood up for.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.8: There are people who deserve neither a seat nor being bowed down to.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.16: There are things that are allowable to receive neither at the right time nor at the wrong time.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.24: There are things that are allowable neither in outlying countries nor in the central Ganges plain.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.28: There are offenses that one commits neither inside nor outside.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.32: There are offenses that one commits neither inside nor outside the monastery zone.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.34: There are offenses that one commits in the wilderness, not in inhabited areas.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.36: There are offenses that one commits neither in inhabited areas nor in the wilderness.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.1: There are four kinds of accusing:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.2: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, prohibiting living together, prohibiting acts of respect.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.3: There are four kinds of preliminary actions.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.4: There are four kinds of seeming appropriate to.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.5: There are four offenses entailing confession concerning “no other”.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.6: There are four kinds of approval from the monks.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.7: There are four ways of acting that are wrong:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.8: one is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.9: There are four ways of acting that are not wrong:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.10: one is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.11: When a shameless monk who has four qualities, he causes a schism in the Sangha:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.12: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and he fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.13: When a good monk who has four qualities, he unites a divided Sangha:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.14: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.15: When a monk has four qualities, he should not be asked about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.16: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.17: When a monk has four qualities, he should not ask about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.18: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.19: When a monk has four qualities, he should not reply to questions about the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.20: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.21: When a monk has three qualities, his questions about the Monastic Law should not be replied to:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.22: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.23: When a monk has four qualities, he should not be allowed to question:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.24: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.25: When a monk has four qualities, one should not discuss the Monastic Law with him:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.26: he is swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.27: There are offenses that one commits when sick, not when not sick.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.28: There are offenses that one commits when not sick, not when sick.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.29: There are offenses that one commits both when sick and when not sick.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.30: There are offenses that one commits neither when sick nor when not sick.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.31: There are four kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.32: There are four kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.1: There are five kinds of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.2: There are five classes of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.3: There are five grounds of training.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.4: There are five kinds of actions with results in the next life.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.5: There are five kinds of people with fixed rebirth.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.6: There are five offenses involving cutting.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.7: There are five reasons for committing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.8: There are five kinds of offenses because of lying.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.9: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is invalid:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.10: one does not do the legal procedure oneself; or one does not request someone else; one does not give one’s consent or declare one’s purity; one objects while the legal procedure is being carried out; or one has the view that the completed legal procedure is illegitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.11: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is valid:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.12: one does the legal procedure oneself; or one requests someone else; one gives one’s consent or declares one’s purity; one does not object while the legal procedure is being carried out; or one has the view that the completed legal procedure is legitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.13: There are five things that are allowable for a monk who is eating almsfood:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.14: visiting families before or after a meal invitation, eating in a group, eating a meal before another, non-determination, non-assignment to another.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.15: When a monk has five qualities—whether he is bad or firm in morality—he is suspected and mistrusted:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.16: he regularly associates with sex workers, widows, single women, paṇḍakas, or nuns.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.17: There are five kinds of oil:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.18: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, and oil from fat.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.19: There are five kinds of fat:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.20: bear fat, fish fat, alligator fat, pig fat, and donkey fat.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.21: There are five kinds of losses:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.22: loss of relatives, loss of property, loss of health, loss in morality, and loss of view.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.23: There are five kinds of successes:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.24: success in relatives, success in property, success in health, success in morality, and success in view.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.25: There are five reasons why the formal support from a preceptor comes to an end:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.26: the preceptor goes away; the preceptor disrobes; the preceptor dies; the preceptor joins another faction; or the preceptor orders it.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.27: There are five kinds of people who should not be given the full ordination:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.28: one lacking in age, one lacking in limbs, one who is deficient as subject, one who has acted wrongly, and one who is incomplete.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.29: There are five kinds of rags:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.30: those from a charnel ground, those from a shop, those eaten by rats, those eaten by termites, those burnt by fire.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.31: There are five other kinds of rags:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.32: those chewed by cattle, those chewed by goats, those left at a stupa, those discarded from a king’s consecration, those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.33: There are five kinds of removing:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.34: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.35: There are five great gangsters to be found in the world.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.36: There are five things not to be given away.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.37: There are five things not to be shared out.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.38: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body, not from speech and mind.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.39: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body and speech, not from mind.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.40: There are five kinds of offenses that are confessable.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.41: There are five kinds of Sanghas.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.42: There are five ways of reciting the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.43: In all outlying countries, the full ordination is to be given by a group of five, including one expert on the Monastic Law.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.44: There are five benefits of performing the robe-making ceremony.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.45: There are five kinds of legal procedures.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.46: There are five “up to three times” offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.47: When five factors are fulfilled, there is an offense entailing expulsion for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.48: When five factors are fulfilled, there is a serious offense for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.49: When five factors are fulfilled, there is an offense of wrong conduct for one who steals.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.50: There are five unallowable things that should not be used:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.51: what has not been given, what is not known about, what is not allowable, what has not been received, and what has not been “made leftover”.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.52: There are five allowable things that may be used:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.53: what has been given, what is known about, what is allowable, what has been received, and what has been “made leftover”.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.54: There are five gifts without merit that are considered meritorious in the world:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.55: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.56: There are five things that are hard to remove:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.57: desire, ill will, confusion, the desire to speak, and the thought of departing.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.58: There are five benefits of sweeping:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.59: one’s own mind becomes serene, the minds of others become serene, the gods are pleased, one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.60: There are five other benefits of sweeping:
pli-tv-pvr7:63.61: one’s own mind becomes serene, the minds of others become serene, the gods are pleased, one carries out the Teacher’s instruction, later generations follow one’s example.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.2: he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.3: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.4: he grasps what is proper for himself to say; he grasps what is proper for others to say; grasping both, he makes them act legitimately, in accordance with their admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.5: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.6: he does not know the offenses; he does not know the sources of offenses; he does not know the origin of offenses; he does not know the ending of offenses; he does not know the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.7: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.8: he knows the offenses; he knows the sources of offenses; he knows the origin of offenses; he knows the ending of offenses; he knows the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.9: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.10: he does not know the legal issues; he does not know the source of the legal issues; he does not know the origin of the legal issues; he does not know the ending of the legal issues; he does not know the path leading to the ending of the legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.11: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.12: he knows legal issues; he knows the source of legal issues; he knows the origin of legal issues; he knows the ending of legal issues; he knows the path leading to the ending of legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.13: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.14: he does not know the actions that are the basis for offenses; he does not know the origin stories; he does not know the rules; he does not know the additions to the rules; he does not know the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.15: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.16: he knows the actions that are the basis for offenses; he knows the origin stories; he knows the rules; he knows the additions to the rules; he knows the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.17: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.18: he does not know the motion; he does not know how the motion is done; he is not skilled in what comes first; he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; he does not know the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.19: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.20: he knows the motion; he knows how the motion is done; he is skilled in what comes first; he is skilled in what comes afterwards; he knows the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.21: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.22: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he has not well-learned or well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.23: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.24: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.25: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.26: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he has not properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, not having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, or investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.27: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.28: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.29: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.30: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he is not skilled in deciding legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.31: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:64.32: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he is skilled in deciding legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.1: There are five kinds of wilderness dwellers:
pli-tv-pvr7:65.2: one may be a wilderness dweller because of stupidity and folly; because one is overcome by bad desires; because of insanity and derangement; because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples; or because of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and wanting it.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.3: There are five kinds of people who only eat almsfood …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.4: There are five kinds of rag-robe wearers …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.5: There are these five kinds of people who live at the foot of a tree …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.6: There are five kinds of people who live in charnel grounds …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.7: There are five kinds of people who live out in the open …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.8: There are five kinds of people who only have three robes …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.9: There are five kinds of people who go on continuous almsround …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.10: There are five kinds of people who never lie down …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.11: There are five kinds of people who accept any resting place …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.12: There are five kinds of people who eat in one sitting per day …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.13: There are five kinds of people who refuse to accept food offered after the meal has begun …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.14: There are five kinds of people who eat only from the almsbowl:
pli-tv-pvr7:65.15: one may be someone who eats only from the almsbowl because of stupidity and folly; because one is overcome by bad desires; because of insanity and derangement; because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples; or because of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and wanting it.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.1: When a monk has five qualities, he should not live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.2: he does not know about the observance-day ceremony; he does not know the observance-day procedure; he does not know the Monastic Code; he does not know the recitation of the Monastic Code; he has less than five years of seniority.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.3: When a monk has five qualities, he may live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.4: he knows about the observance-day ceremony; he knows the observance-day procedure; he knows the Monastic Code; he knows the recitation of the Monastic Code; he has five or more years of seniority.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.5: When a monk has five other qualities, he should not live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.6: he does not know about the invitation ceremony; he does not know the invitation procedure; he does not know the Monastic Code; he does not know the recitation of the Monastic Code; he has less than five years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:66.9: When a monk has five other qualities, he should not live without formal support:

pli-tv-pvr7:66.11: When a monk has five qualities, he may live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.12: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has five or more years of seniority.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.13: A nun who is possessed of five qualities should not live independently:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.14: she does not know about the observance-day ceremony; she does not know the observance-day procedure; she does not know the Monastic Code; she does not know the recitation of the Monastic Code; she has less than five years of seniority.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.15: When a nun has five qualities, she may live without formal support:
pli-tv-pvr7:66.16: she knows about the observance-day ceremony; she knows the observance-day procedure; she knows the Monastic Code; she knows the recitation of the Monastic Code; she has five or more years of seniority.
pli-tv-pvr7:66.17: When a nun has five other qualities, she should not live without formal support:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.1: There are five dangers in being uninspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.2: You criticize yourself; after investigating, wise people condemn you; you get a bad reputation; you die confused; after death, you are reborn in a lower realm.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.3: There are five benefits in being inspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.4: You do not criticize yourself; after investigating, wise people praise you; you get a good reputation; you die unconfused; after death, you are reborn in heaven.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.5: There are five other dangers in being uninspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.6: you hinder confidence in those without it; you cause some to lose their confidence; you don’t carry out the Teacher’s instructions; later generations follow your example; your mind doesn’t become serene.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.7: There are five benefits in being inspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.8: you give rise confidence in those without it; you increase the confidence of those who have it; you carry out the Teacher’s instructions; later generations follow your example; your mind becomes serene.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.9: There are five dangers in associating with families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.10: he commits the offense of visiting families before or after a meal invitation; he commits the offense of sitting in private with a woman; he commits the offense of sitting on a concealed seat with a woman; he commits the offense of teaching more than five or six sentences to a woman; he has a lot of sensual thoughts.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.11: There are five dangers for a monk who associates with families:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.12: when he associates too much with families, he often sees women; because of seeings them, he associates with them; because of associating with them, there is intimacy; because of intimacy, there is weakness; because his mind is overcome by lust, it is to be expected that he will be dissatisfied with the spiritual life, that he commits a certain defiled offense, or that he will renounce the training and return to the lower life.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.1: There are five kinds of propagation:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.2: propagation from roots, propagation from stems, propagation from joints, propagation from cuttings, and propagation from regular seeds as the fifth.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.3: When fruit is allowable for monastics for any of five reasons, it may be eaten:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.4: it has been damaged by fire, it has been damaged by a knife, it has been damaged by a nail, it’s seedless, the seeds have been removed.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.5: There are five kinds of purification:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.6: After reciting the introduction, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.7: After reciting the introduction and the four rules entailing expulsion, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.8: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, and the thirteen rules entailing suspension, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.9: After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, the thirteen rules entailing suspension, and the two undetermined rules, the rest is announced as if heard.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.11: There are five other kinds of purification:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.12: the observance-day ceremony which consists of reciting the Monastic Code, the observance-day ceremony which consists of declaring purity, the observance-day ceremony which consists of a determination, the invitation ceremony, and the unification observance day as the fifth.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.13: There are five benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:68.14: your own morality is well guarded; you are a refuge for those who are habitually anxious; you speak with confidence in the midst of the Sangha; you can legitimately and properly refute an opponent; you are practicing for the longevity of the true Teaching.

pli-tv-pvr7:97.1: When a monk has seven qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:97.2: He knows the offenses. [2] He knows the non-offenses. [3] He knows the light offenses. [4] He knows the heavy offenses. [5] He is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. And he undertakes and trains in the training rules. [6] Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant higher-mind meditations of the present life. [7] And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.
pli-tv-pvr7:98.1: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:98.2: He knows the offenses. [2] He knows the non-offenses. [3] He knows the light offenses. [4] He knows the heavy offenses. [5] He has learned much, and he retains and accumulates what he has learned. Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—he has learned many such teachings, retained them in mind, recited them verbally, mentally investigated them, and penetrated them well by view. [6] Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant higher-mind meditations of the present life. [7] And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

[5] He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition. [6] Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant higher-mind meditations of the present life. pli-tv-pvr7:100.1: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-pvr7:100.2: He knows the offenses. [2] He knows the non-offenses. [3] He knows the light offenses. [4] He knows the heavy offenses. [5] He recollects many past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births; many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, many eons of both dissolution and evolution; and he knows: ‘There I had such name, such family, such appearance, such food, such experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan. Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere, and there I had such name, such family, such appearance, such food, such experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’ In this way he recollects many past lives with their characteristics and particulars. [6] With superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell. But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’ In this way, with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions. [7] And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:125.2: And twice two groups of nine;
pli-tv-pvr7:126.2: There are ten ways of getting rid of resentment.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.3: There are ten grounds of training.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.4: There are ten subject matters of wrong view.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.5: There are ten subject matters of right view.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.8: There are ten kinds of rightness.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.9: There are ten ways of doing unskillful deeds.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.10: There are ten ways of doing skillful deeds.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.11: There are ten reasons why a vote is illegitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.12: There are ten reasons why a vote is legitimate.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.13: There are ten training rules for the novice monks.
pli-tv-pvr7:126.14: A novice monk who has ten qualities should be expelled.
pli-tv-pvr7:127.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:127.2: he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission; he does not know the offenses; he does not know the sources of offenses; he does not know the origin of offenses; he does not know the ending of offenses; he does not know the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:128.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:128.2: he grasps what is proper for himself to say; he grasps what is proper for others to say; grasping both, he makes them act legitimately, in accordance with their admission; he knows the offenses; he knows the sources of offenses; he knows the origin of offenses; he knows the ending of offenses; he knows the path leading to the ending of offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:129.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:129.2: he does not know the legal issues; he does not know the sources of the legal issues; he does not know the origin of the legal issues; he does not know the ending of the legal issues; he does not know the path leading to the ending of the legal issues; he does not know the actions that are the basis for offenses; he does not know the origin stories; he does not know the rules; he does not know the additions to the rules; he does not know the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:130.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:130.2: he knows legal issues; he knows the sources of legal issues; he knows the origin of legal issues; he knows the ending of legal issues; he knows the path leading to the ending of legal issues; he knows the actions that are the basis for offenses; he knows the origin stories; he knows the rules; he knows the additions to the rules; he knows the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:131.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:131.2: he does not know the motion; he does not know how the motion is done; he is not skilled in what comes first; he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; he does not know the right time; he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he has not well-learned or well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
pli-tv-pvr7:132.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:132.2: he knows the motion; he knows how the motion is done; he is skilled in what comes first; he is skilled in what comes afterwards; he knows the right time; he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.
pli-tv-pvr7:133.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as ignorant:
pli-tv-pvr7:133.2: he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he has not properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, not having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition; he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; he does not know the light and heavy offenses; he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; he does not know the grave and minor offenses; he is not skilled in deciding legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:134.1: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is reckoned as wise:
pli-tv-pvr7:134.2: he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition; he knows the offenses and non-offenses; he knows the light and heavy offenses; he knows the curable and incurable offenses; he knows the grave and minor offenses; he is skilled in deciding legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.1: A monk who has ten qualities may be appointed to a committee.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.2: The Buddha laid down the training rules for his disciples for ten reasons.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.3: There are ten dangers in entering a royal compound.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.4: There are ten reasons for giving.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.6: There is a sangha of monks consisting of a group of ten.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.7: A group of ten may give the full ordination.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.8: There are ten kinds of rags.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.9: There are ten kinds of robe wearing.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.10: One should keep an extra robe for ten days at the most.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.13: There are ten kinds of wives.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.14: The ten practices proclaim as allowable at Vesālī.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.15: There are ten kinds of people a monk should not pay respect to.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.16: There are ten kinds of abuse.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.17: There are ten ways of engaging in malicious talebearing.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.18: There are ten kinds of furniture.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.20: There are ten kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.21: These are the ten legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.22: These are the ten benefits of rice porridge.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.23: There are ten kinds of unallowable meat.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.24: There are ten rules about ‘at the most’.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.25: A competent and capable monk who has ten years of seniority may give the going forth, the full ordination, and formal support, and may have a novice monk attend on him.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.26: A competent and capable nun who has ten years of seniority may give the going forth, the full ordination, and formal support, and may have a novice nun attend on her.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.27: A competent and capable nun who has ten years of seniority may agree to be approved to give the full admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.28: The training may be given to a married girl who is ten years old.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.1: There are eleven kinds of people who should not be ordained, and if they have been ordained, they should be expelled.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.18: There are eleven kinds of flaws in monastery zones.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.19: There are eleven dangers to be expected for people who abuse and revile.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.20: There are eleven benefits to be expected for one who practices the liberation of mind through love, who develops, cultivates, and makes it a vehicle and basis, who keeps it up, accumulates, and properly implements it:
pli-tv-pvr7:144.21: you sleep well, wake up rested, and have no nightmares; you are loved by humans and spirits; you are protected by the gods; you cannot be harmed by fire, poison, or weapons; your mind is quickly stilled; your face is serene; you dies unconfused; and if you do not go any further, you are reborn in the world of the supreme beings.”
